awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Graph Theoretical Inference and Predictive Dynamic Modeling of Signal Transduction Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Current understanding of many biological signal transduction processes consists of knowing key mediators and their positive or negative effects on the process as a whole, yet is increasingly recognized that these mediators function in concert with each other and with other possibly unidentified components. This CAREER award project integrates graph inference, network analysis and dynamic modeling approaches into a general framework for reconstructing and modeling biological signal transduction networks from partial and indirect knowledge. The methodology under development allows predictive modeling of partially characterized signaling networks where traditional frameworks cannot be applied.
    The graph synthesis process represents indirect relationships as paths and finds the sparsest graph incorporating all experimental evidence via a minimal binary transitive reduction algorithm. New graph measures of redundancy and centrality are developed to incorporate interaction attributes (sign, timing, synergy) and to elucidate the topological constraints on the dynamical repertoire of signal transduction processes. Stochastic Boolean and piece-wise linear approaches are used to formulate predictive dynamic models of signal transduction networks. The methodology is applied to abscisic acid (ABA) induced stomatal closure, light-induced stomatal opening, and ABA inhibition of seed germination, complex plant biology processes that can eminently serve as model systems to better understand animal signaling.
   A comprehensive interdisciplinary education/outreach plan is implemented which includes but is not restricted to (i) incorporating a simulation component to teaching Solid State Physics, (ii) developing a course in modeling biological systems, and (iii) distilling the developed methods into software modules to be disseminated as bioinformatics services.

por.por_cntn:
In biological systems ranging from the molecular to ecosystem level, higher-level emergent behaviors result from the interacting units of the lower levels. For example, cellular behaviors such as growth, movement or differentiation result from the coordinated interactions among a large number of (macro)molecules. Network modeling, the representation of system of interacting elements with a set of nodes connected pairwise by edges, followed by graph-theoretical analysis of the resultant network, has proven an insightful first step toward understanding the emergent properties of complex biological systems. This project and career-development plan initiated novel network-based modeling approaches suitable for  biological systems for which no kinetic (time-dependent) information is available. 


A significant achievement of this project is the development of a new framework for structural analysis of signal transduction networks (i.e., networks that integrate the interactions and processes initiated by a signal molecule's binding to a receptor protein). This framework naturally incorporates negative regulation and combinatorial or conditionality relations among edges, important features of signal transduction networks which were nevertheless not incorporated by previously studied network analysis methods. A key innovation of this framework is the concept of elementary signaling mode, defined as the minimal set of components that need to mediate a signal in order for it to produce a cellular response. A second significant achievement of this project is the demonstration of the success of qualitative (Boolean) modeling in a variety of contexts, including signal transduction networks in plants and humans, the mammalian immune response to pathogens and mutualistic community formation in ecosystems. The predictions of the models were validated by follow-up experiments. The advances made in the project were reported in more than twenty peer-reviewed articles and seven book chapters. The project also led to the development of freely downloadable software for Boolean network modeling which has been fruitfully used by numerous groups. 


The grant contributed to the interdisciplinary training of eight graduate students, six of whom received their PhDs, two undergraduate students, one of whom received his BS degree, and two postdoctoral researchers. These students and researchers presented their work in talks and posters at national conferences.This grant enabled the PI to develop three interdisciplinary courses, two at the graduate and one at the undergraduate level.The grant contributed to the broadening of the participation of women and minorities in research by its support of six female students/postdocs and two Hispanic students.
